title: Ada Lovelace
fact: She created the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine, which is why she is considered the first computer programmer

title: Adele Goldberg
fact: Is a computer scientist who participated in the development of the programming language Smalltalk-80 and various concepts related to object-oriented programming while a researcher at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, PARC, in the 1970s.

title: Anita Borg
fact: She founded the Institute for Women and Technology and the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing.

title: Women in IT industry
fact: Currently, only 3 out of 10 jobs in the IT industry are held by women.

title: Éva Tardos
fact: Éva Tardos is a Hungarian mathematician, winner of the Fulkerson Prize (1988) for her research on design and analysis of algorithms.

title: Beatrice Helen Worsley
fact: Beatrice Helen Worsley was the first female computer scientist in Canada.

title: The degree gap
fact: While women are less represented in undergrad CS departments, those who do pursue computer science degrees are more likely to dive more deeply these days, as the percentage of master’s degrees in computer science earned by women rose to 31% in 2016, up from 28% in 1997.

title: Carol Shaw
fact: Originally an Atari employee, Carol Shaw is said to be the first female video game designer.

title: Dame Stephanie
fact: She was concerned with creating work opportunities for women with dependants, and predominantly employed women, only 3 out of 300-odd programmers were male, until the Sex Discrimination Act 1975 made that illegal.

title: Nerea Luis
fact: She is an engineer at the company Sngular, doctor cum laude in Artificial Intelligence and one of the young Spanish women with the most promising future in this field.

title: Women in tech Spain
fact: 2019 was the first year in which the percentage of women employed in this sector represented 1% of the total number of employed women in the country

title: Hedy Lamarr
fact: She was a co-inventor, along with George Antheil, of the first version of spread spectrum that would allow long-distance wireless communications.

title: Women Leadership
fact: In Europe, only 5% of leadership positions in the technology industry are held by women

title: Evelyn Boyd
fact: Evelyn Boyd Granville was one of the first African-American women to receive a Ph.D. in mathematics.

title: Frances E. Allen
fact: Frances E. Allen became the first female IBM Fellow in 1989.

title: Frances Spence
fact: Was one of the original programmers for the ENIAC computer, her role as well as the other woman contributors were downplayed, due to the stigma that woman didn't like technology.

title: Grow with STEM
fact: STEM is an exciting and innovative field, with many opportunities for women to launch their careers. Join the technology industry to launch your career and make a difference for your community and the world.

title: Grace Hopper
fact: Was an American computer scientist and United States Navy rear admiral.She was one of the first programmers of the Harvard Mark I computer, and invented the first compiler for a computer programming language.

title: Grete Hermann
fact: Grete (Henry-)Hermann was a German mathematician and philosopher noted for her work in mathematics, physics, philosophy and education.

title: Ida Rhodes
fact: Ida Rhodes was a mathematician who became a member of the clique of influential women at the heart of early computer development in the United States.

title: Irene Greif
fact: Founder of the field of Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW). She was the first woman to earn a Ph.D. in computer science from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Irma Wyman
fact: Was an early computer engineer and the first woman to become vice president of Honeywell.

title: Janese Swanson
fact: Janese Swanson (born 1958) is an American inventor and software developer. Swanson co-developed the first of the Carmen Sandiego educational games, and founded the company Girl Tech.

title: Jean Bartik
fact: Jean Bartik was one of the original programmers for the ENIAC computer.

title: Jean E. Sammet
fact: Developed the FORMAC programming language in 1962.

title: Jeri Ellsworth
fact: Is an American entrepreneur and autodidact computer chip designer and inventor.

title: Joan Margaret Winters
fact: Designed and implemented SPINDEX II applications for the Department of Manuscripts and University Archives.

title: Joanna Rutkowska
fact: Joanna Rutkowska is a Polish computer security researcher, primarily known for her research on low-level security and stealth malware.

title: Judith Estrin
fact: Is an Internet pioneer and American business executive.She is now CEO of JLabs.

title: Juliana Rotich
fact: Currently serves as Chair of World Economic Forum Global Agenda Council on Data Driven Development.

title: Karen Spärck Jones
fact: Holded the post of Professor of Computers and Information, which she was awarded in 1999.

title: Kathleen Booth
fact: Is credited with writing the first assembly language and the design of the assembler and autocode (ARC and APE(X)C) for the first computer systems at Birkbeck College, University of London.

title: Kay McNulty
fact: Was one of the six original programmers of the ENIAC.

title: Kimberly Bryant
fact: Is the Founder and Executive Director of Black Girls CODE.

title: Limor Fried
fact: Limor Fried is an American electrical engineer and owner of the electronics hobbyist company Adafruit Industries.

title: Lorinda Cherry
fact: Lorinda Cherry is a computer programmer. She received her Masters in computer science from Stevens Institute of Technology in 1969.

title: Lynn Conway
fact: Conway was recruited by IBM Research in Yorktown Heights, in 1964, and was soon selected to join the architecture team designing an advanced supercomputer.

title: Maria Klawe
fact: Is a computer scientist and the fifth president of Harvey Mudd College (since July 1, 2006).

title: Marissa Mayer
fact: Is the current president and CEO of Yahoo!

title: Marlyn Wescoff
fact: Marlyn Meltzer was one of the six original programmers of ENIAC.

title: Mary Allen Wilkes
fact: Is a former computer programmer and hardware engineer, most known for her work with the LINC computer.

title: Mary Lou Jepsen
fact: Is Head of the Display Division at Google X. She is also founder and former CEO of Pixel Qi.

title: Mary Shaw
fact: Mary Shaw is an American software engineer, and the Alan J. Perlis Professor of Computer Science in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, United States.

title: Melanie Rieback
fact: Melanie Rieback is a former Asst. Prof. of Computer Science at VU who performelient at Citrix.

title: Monica S. Lam
fact: Is a professor in the Computer Science Department at Stanford, and Founder of MokaFive.

title: Phyllis Fox
fact: Worked on the PORT portable mathematical/numerical library. Fox was part of the team that wrote DYNAMO for Jay Forrester's system dynamics research group.

title: Radia Perlman
fact: Invented the Spanning Tree Protocol. She has done extensive and innovative research particularly on encryption and networking.She holds more than 100 issued patents.

title: Rana el Kaliouby
fact: Is the inventor of expression-recognition technology, which is a subset of facial recognition.

title: Rósa Péter
fact: She is best known for her work with recursion theory.

title: Rebecca Enonchong
fact: Is a Cameroonian born technology entrepreneur and also the founder and CEO of AppsTech. She is best known for her work promoting technology in Africa.
